A Formalization of Image Vectorization by Region Merging

Roy Y. He, Sung Ha Kang, Jean-Michel Morel
Abstract

Image vectorization converts raster images into vector graphics composed of regions separated by curves. Typical vectorization methods first define the regions by grouping similar colored regions via color quantization, then approximate their boundaries by Bézier curves. In that way, the raster input is converted into an SVG format parameterizing the regions’ colors and the Bézier control points. This compact representation has many graphical applications thanks to its universality and resolution-independence. In this paper, we remark that image vectorization is nothing but an image segmentation, and that it can be built by fine to coarse region merging. Our analysis of the problem leads us to propose a vectorization method alternating region merging and curve smoothing. We formalize the method by alternate operations on the dual and primal graph induced from any domain partition. In that way, we address a limitation of current vectorization methods, which separate the update of regional information from curve approximation. We formalize region merging methods by associating them with various gain functionals, including the classic Beaulieu-Goldberg and Mumford-Shah functionals. More generally, we introduce and compare region merging criteria involving region number, scale, area, and internal standard deviation. We also show that the curve smoothing, implicit in all vectorization methods, can be performed by the shape-preserving affine scale space. We extend this flow to a network of curves and give a sufficient condition for the topological preservation of the segmentation. The general vectorization method that follows from this analysis shows explainable behaviors, explicitly controlled by a few intuitive parameters. It is experimentally compared to state-of-the-art software and proved to have comparable or superior fidelity and cost efficiency.

1 Introduction

Image vectorization is a powerful technique that yields tangible benefits to many applications, including shape analysis [48, 50, 53], content editing [81], line-drawing reconstruction [56, 78], and topological data analysis [4]. A raster image is represented by its values on a rectangular grid whose nodes are called pixels. Such a grid-dependent pixel-level representation is inefficient [14, 37, 105] and cumbersome for geometric transformations and analysis [31, 6]. Another limitation is the pixelation effect [15], where pixel corners do not necessarily correspond to perceived shape corners. The goal of vectorization is to represent a raster image by a finite number of parameterized boundary curves and regions with certain rendering rules. The resulting resolution-free representation, called vector graphic, is presented under many variants in the literature [104, 35].

A majority of vectorization methods produce piecewise-constant vector graphics [48, 50, 52, 53, 54, 88, 70], where the composing elements are regions filled with constant colors and enclosed by parametric curves such as lines, arcs, and Bézier curves. These elements are often encoded and organized in a particular format, called Scalable Vector Graphic (SVG) [40]. Most image viewers and web browsers can instantly read and render111Rasterization converts vector graphics back to bitmaps, which is the inverse process of vectorization. This rendering is required to display or print a vector graphic. Since this process is generally real-time, it creates an impression of directly manipulating the SVG files. Rasterization follows instantly after modifying the SVG file via well-designed user interfaces. the contents, and common graphic software such as Adobe Illustrator [3] support interactive editing. There are more advanced forms involving mesh generation [100] and elliptic partial differential equations (PDEs) [81] for photo-realistic smooth vector graphics. Typically, the vectorization process involves edge detection or domain segmentation followed by curve fitting for boundaries of homogeneous regions, and these decisions strongly affect the results’ visual quality. In [49], it was proven that binary raster shape vectorization was optimally performed by affine shortening, and a fast code and online execution of the method is provided [52] for binary images. The method [51] sketches an extension of the silhouette affine shortening to general image vectorization relying on color quantization. A generalized affine shortening is proposed to smooth the set of resulting region boundaries. The method focuses on the question of moving adequately the curves supporting T-junctions [53].

For color or grayscale images, color quantization techniques  [26] are widely applied to find initial domain partitions. Well-known methods include median cut [55], k𝑘kitalic_k-means clustering [72], Octree [43], self-organizing maps [29], and competitive learning [25].

For example, Figure 1 (c) shows a quantization for (a) using k𝑘kitalic_k-means with 5555 colors, and the connected components are then filled with average colors of the pixels therein. The quantized image contains 2418241824182418 connected components. There are many small regions near the shape boundaries and highly irregular contours in homogeneous regions. Dithering [103] or half-toning [45] techniques can be used to reduce such contouring artifacts, but they can create even more regions. Figure 1 (b) shows a domain partition based on a region merging method proposed in this paper. It contains only 151151151151 regions while exhibiting fewer artifacts, thus achieving a highly efficient representation.

A key vectorization criterion is the local regularity of regions and boundaries. The proximity principle in Gestalt theory [89] suggests that the similarities in colors, geometry, or textures of nearby regions facilitate grouping unstructured units. There is also evidence showing that this assimilation process eventually contributes to visual perception [87, 105]. When presented with raster images consisting of thousands of squares of constant colors, human observers tend to perceive smooth boundaries or acute angles while ignoring discrete pixel features. The underlying mechanism has been a source of ongoing discussions and research [34, 83], and it also inspires multiple inventions in computational models that simulate different aspects of visual perception. Among the various developments [27, 23, 61, 19, 66], one of the most celebrated models is the Mumford-Shah functional [77]:

ℰf⁢(u,Γ)=∫Ω∖Γ‖u⁢(𝐱)−f⁢(𝐱)‖22⁢𝑑𝐱+∫Ω∖Γ‖∇u⁢(𝐱)‖22⁢𝑑𝐱+λ⁢∫Γ𝑑σ⁢(𝐱).subscriptℰ𝑓𝑢ΓsubscriptΩΓsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢𝐱𝑓𝐱22differential-d𝐱subscriptΩΓsuperscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑢𝐱22differential-d𝐱𝜆subscriptΓdifferential-d𝜎𝐱\mathcal{E}_{f}(u,\Gamma)=\int_{\Omega\setminus\Gamma}\|u(\mathbf{x})-f(% \mathbf{x})\|_{2}^{2}\,d\mathbf{x}+\int_{\Omega\setminus\Gamma}\|\nabla u(% \mathbf{x})\|_{2}^{2}\,d\mathbf{x}+\lambda\int_{\Gamma}\,d\sigma(\mathbf{x})\;.caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u , roman_Γ ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Ω ∖ roman_Γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_u ( bold_x ) - italic_f ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d bold_x + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Ω ∖ roman_Γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ italic_u ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d bold_x + italic_λ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_σ ( bold_x ) . (1.1)

It models the perceived image u:Ω→ℝd:𝑢→Ωsuperscriptℝ𝑑u:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u : roman_Ω → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (d=1𝑑1d=1italic_d = 1 or 3333) as a regularized approximation for the observation f:Ω→ℝd:𝑓→Ωsuperscriptℝ𝑑f:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_f : roman_Ω → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In (1.1), Γ⊂ℝ2Γsuperscriptℝ2\Gamma\subset\mathbb{R}^{2}roman_Γ ⊂ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the discontinuity set of u𝑢uitalic_u, λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0 is the regularization parameter, and d⁢σ𝑑𝜎d\sigmaitalic_d italic_σ is the length element. The perceptual simplification is characterized by smoothness of continuous regions in the second term and length-minimization in the third term. Its objective is to partition the image domain into finite regions, each of which ideally corresponds to an object characterized by homogeneous interiors or semantically defined as a whole.

There are natural connections between image segmentation and image vectorization. Both areas are motivated by the simplifying process of human visual perception. Natural objectives such as length minimization, contour continuity, and spectral proximity are frequently used in both families of models [86, 77, 98, 76, 35]. They emphasize large-scale or intrinsic geometric features of the image while removing small-scale oscillations caused by pixelation or noise. Secondly, both focus on detecting critical boundary curves such that the interior details of each enclosed region are deemed minute or deductible. The idea initiated by Elder’s studies on edge map [37], followed by Orzan’s development of diffusion curves [81] as well as the further developments [60, 41, 18] for image vectorization is parallel to the road paved by [27, 99, 94] for image segmentation; both streams of work contain interesting discussions about edge strength modeling. On the dual side, both vectorization algorithms such as [110, 39] and segmentation methods including [92, 64, 2] exploit a region-growing strategy. Thirdly, like segmentation, many vectorization algorithms produce partitions of the image domain. Both approaches sometimes appear interchangeable. For example, Prasad and Skourikhine [86] proposed a segmentation method by modifying their mesh-based vectorization using constrained Delaunay triangulation. Lecot and Lévy [67] presented a vectorization model by combining Ilyod’s formulation of Voronoi partition [72] with Mumford-Shah’s length minimization.

The primary challenge in recognizing the significance of local regularity in image vectorization lies in the fact that variational segmentation models such as (1.1) are typically more computationally intensive to address compared to color quantization techniques. Variational models often involve manipulating curves and regions, leading to non-convex and non-smooth optimization problems [65]. Various advanced algorithms [85, 28] and intricate approximations [10] have been developed to address this issue. Recent advancements in neural network-based approaches further reduce the complexity by optimizing the shape and color control points of deformable objects which are initially randomly placed [70, 108, 107]. Since these methods allow for transparent regions with overlaps, the outcomes may not always preserve shapes and can be difficult to edit.

In this paper, we investigate a general and interpretable image vectorization method that is built on region merging and curve smoothing. Starting from each pixel as its own region, we consider several region merging methods associated with classic Mumford-Shah [77], Beaulieu-Goldberg [16], and two new merging methods based on the scale and area of regions. We formulate this procedure as modifications on an image-induced dual graph which represents the adjacency relations among partition regions; we also show that such local decisions yield globally consistent partitions. Then, each region boundary is smoothed by an affine shortening flow, and we analyze a theoretically sufficient condition for topological preservation. We describe this procedure as a transformation on an image-induced primal graph, where image junctions correspond to nodes and boundary curves connecting them correspond to edges. Both components rely on solid foundations whose behaviors are explicitly controlled via user-friendly parameters. We summarize this article’s contributions as follows.

  1. 1.

    We explore a general formulation of image vectorization using region merging based on image segmentation principles.

  2. 2.

    We introduce partition-induced primal and dual graph structures for efficiently integrating region merging and curve smoothing.

  3. 3.

    We discuss the properties of different region merging criteria to show various effects and analyze a sufficient condition for topological preservation during the curve smoothing.

  4. 4.

    We are led to a general vectorization method with explainable parameters, and obtain accurate vectorization results that compare favourably to state-of-the-art vectorization methods.

This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we present the general framework of the investigated models and introduce the primal and dual graph structures. In Section 3, we present the region merging (the dual step) in more depth by exploring and analyzing different region merging criteria. In Section 4, we present the details of curve smoothing (the primal step), including the extension to networks of curves and the investigation of topological preservation. Numerical details are presented in Section 5, which is followed by various experimental results in Section 6. Section 7 concludes the paper.

In this paper, we interpret vectorization as an image simplification process that exploits local color regularity through effective region-merging, while ensuring boundary smoothness via geometric invariant curve smoothing. This leads to using two key operations:

In the region merging process (2.1), the cost of merging two adjacent regions is evaluated and compared with a threshold. The cost of merging models involves color contrast and various shape priors. The merging threshold fixes a desired complexity for the final partition. In the curve smoothing process (2.2), the set of boundary curves, ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ, undergoes an evolution based on a flow ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F moving all curves by a geometrically intrinsic equation with junctions fixed.

We formulate the two processes (2.1) and (2.2) as operations acting on the dual and primal graphs induced from image domain partitions, respectively. The dual graph encodes the adjacency relations among regions in the partition, where each node stands for a connected component, and two nodes are connected by an edge if their corresponding regions are adjacent. The primal graph models the geometry of the partition by denoting each junction point as a node, and two nodes are joined by an edge if they are connected by a boundary curve. In the primal graph, there may be multiple edges between nodes, and there may be isolated edges incident to no nodes. This is illustrated in Figure 2. Associated with the region partition 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P of the given image f𝑓fitalic_f in (a), the dual graph in (b) represents each region Oisubscript𝑂𝑖O_{i}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a node and each adjacency between regions as an edge. The primal graph in (c) represents each junction 𝐏ksubscript𝐏𝑘\mathbf{P}_{k}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a node, and nodes are connected by boundary curves 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that some of the boundary curves 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be closed.

With this setting, our proposed generic method alternates the dual region merging step acting on the dual graph, and the primal curve smoothing step acting on the primal graph. The iteration starts from an input raster image, where pixels viewed as square regions form an initial partition 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. The topology and geometry of the image partition is updated by iterating the primal and dual steps:

  • •

    Dual step: Given the initial partition or the partition from the previous primal step, adjacent regions are merged according to (2.1). This step may change the topology of the partition. The details are discussed in Section 3.

  • •

    Primal step: Given the partition processed by the dual step, the boundary curves evolve by the affine shortening flow (4.1) with suitable boundary conditions. This step reduces pixelation effects while preserving shape corners. The details are in Section 4.

Finally, boundary curves 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the final partition are approximated by parametric curves and the color cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT within each region Oisubscript𝑂𝑖O_{i}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is computed as the mean of the original image colors in Oisubscript𝑂𝑖O_{i}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This leads to generating an SVG file enabling real-time rendering. Figure 3 illustrates the region merging dual step. Starting from the dual graph in (a), the yellow rectangle is merged with the purple region in (b), causing the removal of one node and its incident edges. In (c), the dark region is further merged with the background region. In (d), the yellow disk is merged with the background, leaving two regions in the image domain. The primal process is illustrated in Figure 4. From the raster image in (a), we apply the dual update and obtain the primal graph in (b). It corresponds to the initial condition (T=0.0𝑇0.0T=0.0italic_T = 0.0) for the affine shortening flow (4.1). In (c)-(e), we show the effect of the primal step when T=0.2𝑇0.2T=0.2italic_T = 0.2, T=1.0𝑇1.0T=1.0italic_T = 1.0, and T=1.5𝑇1.5T=1.5italic_T = 1.5, respectively. The curve smoothing denoises each boundary curve while keeping the junction location, i.e., the black dot, to prevent topological changes. More details are presented in Subsection 4.1.

In the following sections, we present the details of the major processes. The dual step of region merging is presented in Section 3, and the primal step of curve smoothing in Section 4. Section 5 contains more implementation details of the proposed algroithm.

3 The Dual Step of Region Merging

In image segmentation, one of the most celebrated models is the Mumford-Shah functional (1.1). It enforces homogeneity within regions delineated by ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ while minimizing the length of ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ for denoising the boundary, which fits well with the vectorization we formulate in this paper. However, the major computational difficulty comes from dealing with curves and regions simultaneously. An alternative approach for pursuing the minimum of such functional is via region-merging [64].

Region merging is a technique used in image processing and computer graphics to form smooth image regions. It works by merging adjacent regions that share similar colors or textures. The iterated merging continues until a stopping criterion is met, which is commonly associated with a desired complexity level. The region merging criteria reflect low-level visual processing privileging contrasted edges and regions with uniform color [84, 46, 57, 16].

The dual graph structure is the key to the efficiency of region merging. In traditional data clustering methods, including most color quantization algorithms, the process of conducting pairwise comparisons requires 𝒪⁢(N2)𝒪superscript𝑁2\mathcal{O}(N^{2})caligraphic_O ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) computations for N𝑁Nitalic_N data points. However, by encoding the adjacency relations, each region is only compared to its neighbors. This significantly reduces the number of comparisons to 𝒪⁢(N⁢R)𝒪𝑁𝑅\mathcal{O}(NR)caligraphic_O ( italic_N italic_R ), where R𝑅Ritalic_R denotes the average number of neighbors. Even with an additional cost of indexing the neighbors, the use of adjacency lists and advanced search algorithms [68] makes this indexing overhead negligible for most applications.

To determine the pairs of adjacent regions to be merged, several criteria inspired by visual perception can be formulated. Brice and Fennema [20] proposed the weakness heuristics for merging condition, which depends on discernible jumps across the shared boundary. Their emphasis on the color jump between neighboring regions closely relates their model to the Kass-Witkin-Terzopoulos model (known as snake model) [63]. The notion of edge strength is the object of numerous works such as [46]. Pavilidis [84] proposed the merging condition as a way to minimize the number of partitioning regions while controlling the approximation error. Beaulieu and Goldberg [16] cast the region merging paradigm as a sequential optimization process and deduced a simple merging condition: merge O1subscript𝑂1O_{1}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with O2subscript𝑂2O_{2}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if

Δ⁢E⁢(O1,O2)≤min⁡(minOi∼Oj⁡(Δ⁢E⁢(Oi,Oj)),λ).Δ𝐸subscript𝑂1subscript𝑂2subscriptsimilar-tosubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗Δ𝐸subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗𝜆\displaystyle\Delta E(O_{1},O_{2})\leq\min(\min_{O_{i}\sim O_{j}}(\Delta E(O_{% i},O_{j})),\lambda)\;.roman_Δ italic_E ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ roman_min ( roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Δ italic_E ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , italic_λ ) . (3.1)

In the formula above,

Δ⁢E⁢(O1,O2)=Var⁢(f,O1∪O2)−Var⁢(f,O1)−Var⁢(f,O2),Var⁢(f,O)=∫O‖f⁢(𝐱)−f¯⁢(O)‖22⁢𝑑𝐱,formulae-sequenceΔ𝐸subscript𝑂1subscript𝑂2Var𝑓subscript𝑂1subscript𝑂2Var𝑓subscript𝑂1Var𝑓subscript𝑂2Var𝑓𝑂subscript𝑂superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑓𝐱¯𝑓𝑂22differential-d𝐱\Delta E(O_{1},O_{2})=\text{Var}(f,O_{1}\cup O_{2})-\text{Var}(f,O_{1})-\text{% Var}(f,O_{2}),\quad\text{Var}(f,O)=\int_{O}\|f(\mathbf{x})-\overline{f}(O)\|_{% 2}^{2}\,d\mathbf{x}\;,roman_Δ italic_E ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = Var ( italic_f , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - Var ( italic_f , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - Var ( italic_f , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , Var ( italic_f , italic_O ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_f ( bold_x ) - over¯ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_O ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d bold_x , (3.2)

Notably, the condition (3.1) is global and gradual.

The above region merging condition can be derived for several examples of variational models as a discrete gradient descent. Conversely, some merging conditions lead to schemes approximately minimizing certain functionals [76, 91]. For example, Koepfler, Lopez, and Morel [64] considered the reduced piecewise constant MS model [77]

ℰf⁢(u)=∫Ω∖Γ‖u⁢(𝐱)−f⁢(𝐱)‖22⁢𝑑𝐱+λ⁢∫Γ𝑑σ⁢(𝐱),subscriptℰ𝑓𝑢subscriptΩΓsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢𝐱𝑓𝐱22differential-d𝐱𝜆subscriptΓdifferential-d𝜎𝐱\mathcal{E}_{f}(u)=\int_{\Omega\setminus\Gamma}\|u(\mathbf{x})-f(\mathbf{x})\|% _{2}^{2}\,d\mathbf{x}+\lambda\int_{\Gamma}\,d\sigma(\mathbf{x}),\;caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Ω ∖ roman_Γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_u ( bold_x ) - italic_f ( bold_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d bold_x + italic_λ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_σ ( bold_x ) , (3.3)

where the approximating image is constrained to have a piecewise constant color. They proposed an efficient region merging algorithm to attain a suboptimal segmentation for (3.3) where Δ⁢E⁢(Oi,Oj)Δ𝐸subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗\Delta E(O_{i},O_{j})roman_Δ italic_E ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (3.1) is changed to

(3.4)

Formula (3.4) involves both local color comparison and geometric regularity, thus it improves on simpler thresholding methods [84, 76]. This algorithm enjoys compactness properties ensuring in particular the elimination of small regions (Section 3.2 in [64]). The expression (3.4) was similarly derived in the context of statistical image segmentation [111, 32, 102]. Other region merging methods may not directly involve variational formulations, including watershed techniques [47], homograms [30], and local histograms [17].

3.1 Merging costs and gain functions

We propose a unifying formulation to explore various region merging criteria. We use (3.1) as a generic merging condition, and refer to λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0 as a threshold parameter. Given a partition 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P of an image f𝑓fitalic_f, we introduce a generic merging cost as

We define the denominator 𝒢⁢(Oi,Oj)𝒢subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗\mathcal{G}(O_{i},O_{j})caligraphic_G ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of (3.5) as the gain functional. The numerator of (3.5) is the drop in the quadratic approximation error of the image by a piecewise constant image caused by merging Oisubscript𝑂𝑖O_{i}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ojsubscript𝑂𝑗O_{j}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Region merging segmentation is a step-wise optimization [16], and the choice of the merging cost progressively determines the model’s behavior. We consider various region merging criteria and study their effects for image vectorization. We start with two classical approaches:

  • •

    Beaulieu-Goldberg (BG) region merging. This is the simplest criterion by taking a constant gain functional

    𝒢BG⁢(Oi,Oj)=1.subscript𝒢BGsubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗1\displaystyle\mathcal{G}_{\text{BG}}(O_{i},O_{j})=1\;.caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 . (3.6)

    This leads to the Beaulieu-Goldberg region merging criterion in (3.1).

  • •

    The Mumford-Shah (MS) region merging. Generalizing from (3.4), we define the (reduced) Mumford-Shah gain as the length of the shared boundary

    𝒢MS⁢(Oi,Oj)=ℋ1⁢(∂Oi∩∂Oj).subscript𝒢MSsubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗\displaystyle\mathcal{G}_{\text{MS}}(O_{i},O_{j})=\mathcal{H}^{1}(\partial O_{% i}\cap\partial O_{j})\;.caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT MS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3.7)

    Two adjacent regions are eligible for merging if either they have very similar colors, or their shared boundary is long. As discussed in [64], this gives a minimizing sequence of partitions for the reduced Mumford-Shah (3.3), and the threshold parameter λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ corresponds to the regularization parameter.

We also propose to compare the above classic merging criteria to the following new ones, which are based on region scale and region area.

  • •

    Scale region merging. The scale of a region O𝑂Oitalic_O is measured by a ratio between its area and perimeter. This ratio is closely related to the Cheeger constant [69], which is also associated with the scale-filtering property of minimizers of Rudin-Osher-Fatemi (ROF) model [5]. This scale is used in [93] for weighted length-minimization. It stabilizes the multiphase segmentation processes and helps find larger and more convex regions. Moreover, it is shown to allow more detailed boundaries [62].

    We shall also test the Scale region merging using the following gain:

    𝒢scale⁢(Oi,Oj)=ℋ1⁢(∂Oi)|Oi|+ℋ1⁢(∂Oj)|Oj|−ℋ1⁢(∂Oi)+ℋ1⁢(∂Oj)−2⁢ℋ1⁢(∂Oi∩∂Oj)|Oi∪Oj|.subscript𝒢scalesubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑖superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑗subscript𝑂𝑗superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑖superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑗2superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗\displaystyle\mathcal{G}_{\text{scale}}(O_{i},O_{j})=\frac{\mathcal{H}^{1}(% \partial O_{i})}{|O_{i}|}+\frac{\mathcal{H}^{1}(\partial O_{j})}{|O_{j}|}-% \frac{\mathcal{H}^{1}(\partial O_{i})+\mathcal{H}^{1}(\partial O_{j})-2% \mathcal{H}^{1}(\partial O_{i}\cap\partial O_{j})}{|O_{i}\cup O_{j}|}\;.caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT scale end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG + divide start_ARG caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG - divide start_ARG caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - 2 caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG .     The gain function (3.7) is established by comparing the lengths of the discontinuity set before and after the merging. Similarly, Formula (3.8) can be derived from comparing the scales of the adjacent regions with the scale of their union. In (3.8), a larger value of 𝒢scale⁢(Oi,Oj)subscript𝒢scalesubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗\mathcal{G}_{\text{scale}}(O_{i},O_{j})caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT scale end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) indicates that Oi∪Ojsubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗O_{i}\cup O_{j}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has a larger scale than either Oisubscript𝑂𝑖O_{i}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Ojsubscript𝑂𝑗O_{j}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT individually.   • •

    Area region merging. We also propose the Area region merging with a simple gain

    𝒢area⁢(Oi,Oj)=max⁡(|Oi|,|Oj|)|Oi∪Oj|.subscript𝒢areasubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗\displaystyle\mathcal{G}_{\text{area}}(O_{i},O_{j})=\frac{\max(|O_{i}|,|O_{j}|% )}{|O_{i}\cup O_{j}|}\;.caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT area end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG roman_max ( | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) end_ARG start_ARG | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG .     It computes the proportion of the larger region in a union of two adjacent regions. Notice that it is bounded between 1/2121/21 / 2 and 1111. When two adjacent regions have equal areas, the gain of merging them equals 1/2121/21 / 2; when one of the adjacent regions has a much larger area than the other, the gain is close to 1111. Area region merging thus prefers merging small regions with adjacent large regions, which is adequate to remove small boundary regions caused by antialiasing. By Proposition 3.1 (below), the merging condition associated with (3.9) can be written as

    min⁡(|O1|,|O2|)⋅‖f¯⁢(O1)−f¯⁢(O2)‖22<λ,⋅subscript𝑂1subscript𝑂2superscriptsubscriptnorm¯𝑓subscript𝑂1¯𝑓subscript𝑂222𝜆\min(|O_{1}|,|O_{2}|)\cdot\|\overline{f}(O_{1})-\overline{f}(O_{2})\|_{2}^{2}<% \lambda\;,roman_min ( | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) ⋅ ∥ over¯ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - over¯ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_λ , (3.10)

    which generalizes the heuristic criterion in [54].

See Appendix A. ∎

We illustrate one of the key differences among these merging criteria in Figure 5. The image in (a) shows a spiral on the left, three squares in the middle, and one square with three horizontal strips on the right. The spiral consists of 121 pixels with intensity 131131131131. In the central section, the squares vary in area from top to bottom: the first square has an area of 25 and an intensity value of 140, the second square has an area of 16 with an intensity of 110, and the third square has an area of 4 with an intensity value of 255. On the right side, the square contains three distinct strips: the upper strip has 3 pixels in height with an intensity of 190, the middle strip has a height of 4 pixels with an intensity of 85, and the lower strip also has a height of 4 pixels but with an intensity value of 180. Figure 5 (b)-(e) show the results of merging using different criteria until only 7 regions (the first row) and 5 regions (the second row) remain.

In the first row, the MS region merging (3.7) in (e) privileges shapes with shorter boundaries, thus it eliminates the spiral immediately. Meanwhile, BG, Scale, and Area all decide to merge the dimmer middle square with the background. In the second row, different merging methods exhibit distinct behaviors. Notice that Area merges the bright small square and the middle strip in the right square with the background. BG merges the stripes in the right square to form a uniform region. Scale merges the bright square with the background and the middle strip in the right square with the bottom one. MS merges the central middle dim square with the background and the middle strip with the lower strip in the right square.

These behaviors are consistent with their respective gains. Area prefers larger and more contrasted shapes, regardless of their perimeters, thus the spirals are preserved while two of the smaller central squares are removed. Since the strips have similar areas, their merging gains are close to 1/2121/21 / 2, which explains why the middle strip merges with the background instead. For BG, the merging decisions solely rely on intensity values, and the resulting images are as close as possible to the input in average. Scale prefers forming large scale objects, and the spiral remains when N=5𝑁5N=5italic_N = 5 due to its intensity; if we lower its intensity, the spiral will be merged with the background. Since the gain grows with the length of shared boundary, MS tends to oversimplify the image by removing elongated shapes, yet preserving bright shapes with relatively short perimeters. We compare these merging methods with more complicated images in Section 6.

Remark 3.1.

Several merging conditions can be derived from general variational models of the following form

Remark 3.2.

We note that the Scale region merging gain (3.8) is different from scale maximization, which corresponds to the following gain function

𝒢scale-max⁢(Oi,Oj)=|Oi∪Oj|ℋ1⁢(∂Oi)+ℋ1⁢(∂Oj)−2⁢ℋ1⁢(∂Oi∩∂Oj).subscript𝒢scale-maxsubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑖superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑗2superscriptℋ1subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗\displaystyle\mathcal{G}_{\text{scale-max}}(O_{i},O_{j})=\frac{|O_{i}\cup O_{j% }|}{\mathcal{H}^{1}(\partial O_{i})+\mathcal{H}^{1}(\partial O_{j})-2\mathcal{% H}^{1}(\partial O_{i}\cap\partial O_{j})}\;.caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT scale-max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG | italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - 2 caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ ∂ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG . (3.15)

The gain functional in (3.15) always prefers merging regions if their union has a large scale, and this is especially true when the scale of one of the adjacent regions is already large. In contrast, the gain in (3.8) focuses on the changes. Since merging a small-scale region with a large-scale region may not contribute to a significant increment in the scale, (3.8) can lead to partitions with more balanced scales.

3.2 Properties of the new region merging methods

In this section, we establish analytical properties of Scale region merging (3.8) and Area region merging (3.9). We find that while the gain functional is established for pairs of neighboring regions, it has an impact on the global properties of the partitions. Generalizing from [64], we say that a partition 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is 2-normal with respect to a merging cost (3.5) if Δ⁢E⁢(Oi,Oj)>λΔ𝐸subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗𝜆\Delta E(O_{i},O_{j})>\lambdaroman_Δ italic_E ( italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > italic_λ for any pairs of adjacent regions Oi,Oj∈𝒫subscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑂𝑗𝒫O_{i},O_{j}\in\mathcal{P}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P. A partition that is 2-normal with respect to one merging cost may not be 2-normal regarding a different one, e.g., see Figure 5. For a fixed merging cost, it is possible to have multiple 2222-normal partitions. In the following analysis, we assume that f𝑓fitalic_f is not a constant image.

Firstly, we analyze the Scale region merging with the gain functional (3.8).

We discuss some interesting aspects of these results in the following remarks.

Remark 3.4.

Thanks to the uniform boundedness of the number of regions and thus the number of edges, by the Arzelá-Ascoli theorem, we may extract a subsequence from a sequence of 2-normal segmentations that converges to some segmentation in the Hausdorff metric. However, the limit segmentation might have a larger energy than the inf-limit of the energies of the minimizing sequences. Nevertheless, if we consider segmentations that are unions of pixels, then their number is finite and we can claim that the minimum exists in this class.

Remark 3.5.

We make a comparison on the upper-bounds for the number of regions in 2-normal partitions using MS, Scale, and Area region merging. In [64], the upper-bound for #⁢𝒫#𝒫\#\mathcal{P}# caligraphic_P using MS is proved:

#⁢𝒫≤|Ω|⁢ωf4C′⁢λ2,#𝒫Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑓4superscript𝐶′superscript𝜆2\#\mathcal{P}\leq\frac{|\Omega|\omega_{f}^{4}}{C^{\prime}\lambda^{2}}\;,# caligraphic_P ≤ divide start_ARG | roman_Ω | italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (3.20)

where C′>0superscript𝐶′0C^{\prime}>0italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 is an absolute constant. For all merging methods, increasing λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ or reducing the image contrasts yields fewer regions. Specifically, for both MS and Scale region merging, since their respective upper-bound depends on the second order of λ−1superscript𝜆1\lambda^{-1}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, increasing λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ tends to cause more regions to be merged compared to Area region merging. For smaller images, i.e., smaller |Ω|Ω|\Omega|| roman_Ω |, we expect that MS and Scale region merging behave similarly.

4 The Curve Smoothing Primal Step

Starting from an image partition 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, the primal step smooths each boundary curve 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to reduce the pixelation effect of the raster image. We define an appropriate framework for evolving the discontinuity set of an image partition via curve evolution equations. Focusing on the affine shortening flow [95], we also present a sufficient condition for the maximal evolution time to preserve the topology of primal graph. Geometric PDEs for planar curve evolution have high relevance in shape analysis because of their intrinsic relations with subgroups of the planar projective group [7, 79, 101] such as the group of similarities or of affine maps. This means that local geometric features of the evolved curves remain stable under perspective changes, which is desirable in most image and shape processing tasks. For any connected Lie group, it is possible to symmetrically derive the corresponding differential invariant flows by solving equations of prolongations of the infinitesimal generator [79]. As shown in [58, 11], general differential invariant flows can exhibit complex behaviors including developing singularities. However, imposing additional properties such as a comparison principle and causality leads to second-order PDEs [7] whose solutions constitute scale-space frameworks for image analysis. An example involving the planar Euclidean group generated by translations and rotations, is the mean curvature flow [22]. The existence and uniqueness of its solution were established by Gage and Hamilton [42] and Grayson [44]. Some numerical techniques include finite differences [24], finite elements [36], the level-set method [82], and the Merriman-Bence-Osher (MBO) scheme [74].

A flow that is symmetric under the special affine group, consisting of translation and transformations by the special linear group SL⁢(ℝ2)SLsuperscriptℝ2\text{SL}(\mathbb{R}^{2})SL ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), is the affine shortening flow [95, 7]

∂𝒞∂t=κ1/3⁢𝐍,𝒞𝑡superscript𝜅13𝐍\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{C}}{\partial t}=\kappa^{1/3}\mathbf{N}\;,divide start_ARG ∂ caligraphic_C end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_t end_ARG = italic_κ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_N , (4.1)

where κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ is the curve’s curvature and 𝐍𝐍\mathbf{N}bold_N its normal direction (More details in Subsection 5.2). The affine shortening flow (4.1) enjoys many desirable properties [12]. Firstly, it effectively eliminates small-scale irregularities while preserving significant curvature features such as corners. Secondly, the curve smoothing process commutes with special affine transformations, guaranteeing that the shape simplification is not affected by general perspective changes.

Some properties and existence theory were discussed and developed in a series of works [95, 12, 7]. Angenent, Sapiro, and Tannenbaum [95] showed that any closed planar curve converges to an elliptical point [12], indicating preservation of critical shape features such as corners. This is different from the asymptotic behavior of the mean curvature flow (which is similar to (4.1), but without the cubic root). Alvarez and Morel [8] conduct a comparison of corner displacement resulting from the curve shortening flow with that observed in the affine shortening flow. They conclude that the affine shortening flow is more effective for corner detection [6]. Similar conclusions were made for image curvature microscopic analysis [31] and image vectorization [50, 52, 53]. Numerically, the affine shortening flow (4.1) can be efficiently addressed by Moisan’s geometric scheme [75, 71], which amounts to finding the envelope of midpoints of chords that enclose small areas. More general differential schemes invariant to planar projective actions are discussed in [38].

4.1 Curve evolution and preservation of topology

The collection of curves ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ and the evolution time T𝑇Titalic_T of the affine shortening flow need to satisfy certain conditions for the primal step to be well-defined. Evolving individual curves in parallel can cause topological changes to the domain partition, leading to inconsistent labels [53]. To avoid such issues, we define the geometric conditions satisfied by ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ in the following, and we provide a theoretical upper bound on the maximal evolution time to ensure the topological invariance of the primal graph.

For any n=1,2,…,N𝑛12…𝑁n=1,2,\dots,Nitalic_n = 1 , 2 , … , italic_N. In this work, we fix all the junction points 𝐏ksubscript𝐏𝑘\mathbf{P}_{k}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when evolving curves. For general curvature-driven evolution of networks of curves with movable junctions, the problem of short-time existence is more delicate and is mainly investigated in the case of a mean curvature flow with non-trivial tangential components [106, 73].

Although the evolution with fixed junctions is simplified, it requires a non-trivial analysis. If we take T𝑇Titalic_T too large, curves with fixed endpoints 𝐏1,𝐏2subscript𝐏1subscript𝐏2\mathbf{P}_{1},\mathbf{P}_{2}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with 𝐏1≠𝐏2subscript𝐏1subscript𝐏2\mathbf{P}_{1}\neq\mathbf{P}_{2}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will converge to a line segment connecting 𝐏1subscript𝐏1\mathbf{P}_{1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐏2subscript𝐏2\mathbf{P}_{2}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; and closed curves can shrink to an ellipse point [95]. This leads to vanishing of regions or generation of new regions when curve interiors intersect with junctions. Figure 6 illustrates the case.

To avoid such circumstances, the maximal evolution time should be controlled as follows.

Proposition 4.2.

If the evolution time T𝑇Titalic_T satisfies

T<1(2⁢2)1/3≈0.7071,𝑇1superscript22130.7071\displaystyle T<\frac{1}{(2\sqrt{2})^{1/3}}\approx 0.7071\;,italic_T < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ( 2 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ≈ 0.7071 , (4.3)

then the affine shortening flow does not alter the topology of ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ.

Proof.

See Appendix D. ∎

The upper-bound in (4.3) is pessimistic. Experimental evidence shows that T≤1.0𝑇1.0T\leq 1.0italic_T ≤ 1.0 suffices to remove pixelation effects while preserving critical shape characteristics.

4.2 Asynchronous effect in dual-primal iteration

Thanks to the maximal evolution time derived in Proposition 4.2, the primal step does not alter the topology of the dual graph. Moreover, the dual step does not affect the smoothness of the primal graph. This allows us to proceed the primal and dual step alternatively. Before extending this idea to develop our algorithm in Section 5, we discuss an important interplay between the dual and primal step.

In Figure 7 (a), the initial curve is given as an open Z-shape curve whose endpoints are junctions, which we label as 𝐏1subscript𝐏1\mathbf{P}_{1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at (0,−3)03(0,-3)( 0 , - 3 ) and 𝐏2subscript𝐏2\mathbf{P}_{2}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at (3,3)33(3,3)( 3 , 3 ). In (b), the shape of the initial curve is the same as in (a), but with additional junction points 𝐏3subscript𝐏3\mathbf{P}_{3}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (labeled First) at (1,3)13(1,3)( 1 , 3 ), and 𝐏4subscript𝐏4\mathbf{P}_{4}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (labeled Second) at (2,−3)23(2,-3)( 2 , - 3 ). For (a), we apply the affine smoothing till T=1.0𝑇1.0T=1.0italic_T = 1.0, while for (b), we apply the affine smoothing twice, each evolving with T=0.5𝑇0.5T=0.5italic_T = 0.5. In addition, in (b) we assume that during the first dual iteration the junction point 𝐏3subscript𝐏3\mathbf{P}_{3}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is removed, and during the second dual iteration the junction point 𝐏4subscript𝐏4\mathbf{P}_{4}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is removed. In (b), notice that the segment with nodes (0,−3),(1,3)0313(0,-3),(1,3)( 0 , - 3 ) , ( 1 , 3 ) and (2,−3)23(2,-3)( 2 , - 3 ) undergoes longer evolution by the affine shortening flow compared to the other part of the curve. The results in (c) show the comparison between the final curve in (a) (dotted curve), and the final curve from (b) (solid curve). In particular, both curves have the same 𝐏1subscript𝐏1\mathbf{P}_{1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐏2subscript𝐏2\mathbf{P}_{2}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as primal graph nodes, but the dotted curve is smoother than the solid one.

This shows the asynchronous effect of the interplay between dual and primal step. It helps to keep details while smoothing the curves. This approach aligns well with the property of Area, BG, and Scale region merging methods which preserve well regional details, as discussed in Subsection 3.1. We note that, for the closed curves containing no junction points, these two schemes with T=1𝑇1T=1italic_T = 1 or T=0.5𝑇0.5T=0.5italic_T = 0.5 twice lead to identical results. This is consistent with the semigroup property [22] of the affine shortening flow applied to a single closed curve.

5 Proposed Algorithm and Implementation Details

In this section, we describe our proposed algorithm for accurate image vectorization with more details.

Besides the obvious upper bound, N0subscript𝑁0N_{0}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for the number of merging operations, the value of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ also determines a natural terminating condition. The merging process stops whenever the cost of merging every pair of adjacent regions exceeds λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, i.e., the corresponding partition is 2222-normal (See Section 3.2). Hence, λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ can be treated as a parameter that controls the number of regions in the final partition. This relation between λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ and the number of regions is implicit and hard to handle. In Section 5.4, we introduce a strategy for a convenient control of the partition complexity.

5.2 Primal Step: Curve smoothing on the primal graph

Hence, the longtime existence of the solution is guaranteed.
