    Case II: If 𝒞m⁢(0)≠𝒞m⁢(Lm⁢(0))subscript𝒞𝑚0subscript𝒞𝑚subscript𝐿𝑚0\mathcal{C}_{m}(0)\neq\mathcal{C}_{m}(L_{m}(0))caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) ≠ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) ) or 𝒞m⁢(0)=𝒞m⁢(Lm⁢(0))=𝐏ksubscript𝒞𝑚0subscript𝒞𝑚subscript𝐿𝑚0subscript𝐏𝑘\mathcal{C}_{m}(0)=\mathcal{C}_{m}(L_{m}(0))=\mathbf{P}_{k}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) = caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) ) = bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for 𝐏ksubscript𝐏𝑘\mathbf{P}_{k}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being a junction point or on ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega∂ roman_Ω, we use a Dirichlet boundary condition:

    𝒞m⁢(0,t)=𝒞m⁢(0,0)⁢and⁢𝒞m⁢(Lm⁢(t),t)=𝒞m⁢(Lm⁢(0),0),t∈[0,T],formulae-sequencesubscript𝒞𝑚0𝑡subscript𝒞𝑚00andsubscript𝒞𝑚subscript𝐿𝑚𝑡𝑡subscript𝒞𝑚subscript𝐿𝑚00𝑡0𝑇\displaystyle\mathcal{C}_{m}(0,t)=\mathcal{C}_{m}(0,0)\leavevmode\nobreak\ % \text{and}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathcal{C}_{m}(L_{m}(t),t)=\mathcal{C}_{m}(L_{% m}(0),0)\;,\quad t\in[0,T]\;,caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 , italic_t ) = caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 , 0 ) and caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) , italic_t ) = caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) , 0 ) , italic_t ∈ [ 0 , italic_T ] , (5.5)

    so that if a curve intersects with other curves or with the boundary of the image domain, the intersections remain fixed during the evolution. By the arc-length evolution formula proved in Lemma 4 of [95], the distance comparison principle (Theorem 2.1 in [59]) established for the mean curvature flow can be generalized to the affine shortening flow applying on smoothly embedded intervals, which can lead to the desired long-time existence and regularity of the solution.

Both scenarios can be consistently and efficiently handled by Moisan’s scheme [75] with expected behaviors. We thus focus on the numerical aspects, and refer interested readers to [58, 59, 95, 12] for more theoretical discussions related to curve shortening flow.

5.3 Algorithm and model parameters

Algorithm 1 presents the pseudo-code of our proposed scheme. Given a raster image f:Ω→ℝd:𝑓→Ωsuperscriptℝ𝑑f:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_f : roman_Ω → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (d=1𝑑1d=1italic_d = 1 or 3333) with N𝑁Nitalic_N pixels and a merging condition associated with a chosen gain functional, our method requires two model parameters:

  • •

    Region number (1≤N∗<N1superscript𝑁𝑁1\leq N^{*}<N1 ≤ italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_N): This parameter specifies an approximation for the number of regions in the output. The actual number can be different from N∗superscript𝑁N^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. See the discussions in Section 5.4.

  • •

    Boundary smoothing time (T∗>0superscript𝑇0T^{*}>0italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0): This parameter specifies the desired level of smoothness of the boundary curves of the resulting partition.

and two algorithmic parameters:

  • •

    The error threshold for approximation (τ>0𝜏0\tau>0italic_τ > 0): The maximal Hausdorff distance allowable for the piecewise Bézier curves approximating the smoothed segmentation boundaries.

  • •

    The number (Imax≥1subscript𝐼1I_{\max}\geq 1italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 1) of alternations of the dual and primal step.

In each dual step, we merge ⌈(N∗−N0)/Imax⌉superscript𝑁subscript𝑁0subscript𝐼\lceil(N^{*}-N_{0})/I_{\max}\rceil⌈ ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⌉ pairs of regions. We use the priority queue [90] to store pairs of adjacent regions with their associated costs of merging. The pair with the lowest cost can be retrieved efficiently by the Pop operation with complexity 𝒪⁢(log⁡n)𝒪𝑛\mathcal{O}(\log n)caligraphic_O ( roman_log italic_n ), where n𝑛nitalic_n denotes the size of the queue. In each primal step, we use the output from the dual step as the initial condition and evolve it according to the affine shortening flow (4.1) for a short time T∗/Imaxsuperscript𝑇subscript𝐼T^{*}/I_{\max}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by the Moisan’s scheme [75]. The number of merged pairs and the evolution time for each dual and primal step respectively are determined such that the total number of merged pairs is around (N∗−N0)superscript𝑁subscript𝑁0(N^{*}-N_{0})( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the total evolution time equals T∗superscript𝑇T^{*}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

After Imaxsubscript𝐼I_{\max}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT times of alternating the dual and primal steps, we employ the post-processing described in Section 5.4. We keep merging adjacent regions in the partition until all the resulting pairs of adjacent regions have costs of merging greater than λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To suppress pixelation effects from the additional mergings, we smooth the boundary curves by the affine shortening flow with a small duration Δ⁢tΔ𝑡\Delta troman_Δ italic_t. We fix Δ⁢t=0.01Δ𝑡0.01\Delta t=0.01roman_Δ italic_t = 0.01 in this work.

5.4 The terminating condition and the final number of regions

As discussed in Section 5.1, the value of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ implicitly controls the number of regions in the final partition. The maximal number of mergings Kmaxsubscript𝐾K_{\max}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be implicitly specified via λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ. For a fixed λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, the merging stops if for some kλ∈ℤsubscript𝑘𝜆ℤk_{\lambda}\in\mathbb{Z}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_Z, Δ⁢Ei,jkλ>λΔsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖𝑗subscript𝑘𝜆𝜆\Delta E_{i,j}^{k_{\lambda}}>\lambdaroman_Δ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_λ holds for all pairs of adjacent regions Oi(kλ),Oj(kλ)superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑖subscript𝑘𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑂𝑗subscript𝑘𝜆O_{i}^{(k_{\lambda})},O_{j}^{(k_{\lambda})}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in 𝒫(kλ)superscript𝒫subscript𝑘𝜆\mathcal{P}^{(k_{\lambda})}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and we have

Kmax=kλ.subscript𝐾subscript𝑘𝜆\displaystyle K_{\max}=k_{\lambda}\;.italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (5.6)

Alternatively, we can fix λ=+∞𝜆\lambda=+\inftyitalic_λ = + ∞ and set a targeted number of regions N∗≤N0superscript𝑁subscript𝑁0N^{*}\leq N_{0}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and let

Kmax=N0−N∗.subscript𝐾subscript𝑁0superscript𝑁\displaystyle K_{\max}=N_{0}-N^{*}\;.italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (5.7)

An advantage of the implicit stopping criterion (5.6) over the explicit one (5.7) is its uniformity. All regions of the resulting partition satisfy the desired geometric property or relations with their respective neighbors specified by the gain functional. Such an appropriate λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is strongly influenced by the image contents. Typically, for images with rich details, λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should be small; and for images dominated by large homogeneous patches, λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should be large. This is analogous to the scale-selection property of the MS model [64, 77]. Yet, depending on the choice of gain functional, the range of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ can be very different. For instance, the parameter λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ corresponding to the Mumford-Shah criterion (3.7) has the same dimension as length; whereas the parameter λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ corresponding to the area criterion (3.9) has the same dimension as area. On the other hand, (5.7) compared to (5.6) is more convenient. It offers a direct control of the a priori complexity of the resulted partition.

To combine the benefits of both stopping criteria, we allow the user to specify the approximate number of regions N∗superscript𝑁N^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and we define λ∗=0superscript𝜆0\lambda^{*}=0italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0. We apply the region merging process for N0−N∗subscript𝑁0superscript𝑁N_{0}-N^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT times. Every time we merge a pair of regions O𝑂Oitalic_O and O′superscript𝑂′O^{\prime}italic_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we update λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by the maximum of the merging cost and the current value for λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e.,

λ∗←max⁡{Δ⁢E⁢(O,O′),λ∗}.←superscript𝜆Δ𝐸𝑂superscript𝑂′superscript𝜆\displaystyle\lambda^{*}\leftarrow\max\{\Delta E(O,O^{\prime}),\lambda^{*}\}\;.italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ← roman_max { roman_Δ italic_E ( italic_O , italic_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } . (5.8)

After N0−N∗subscript𝑁0superscript𝑁N_{0}-N^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT merging rounds, we continue iterating the merging procedure until the implicit stopping criterion holds for λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By doing so, we ensure that merging any pair of adjacent regions of the resulting partition would invoke greater costs. Consequently, the number of regions in the resulting partition can be smaller than N∗superscript𝑁N^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

6 Numerical Experiments

In this experimental section, we discuss and compare the properties of vectorization algorithms. For the proposed vectorization method, we fix T∗=1.0superscript𝑇1.0T^{*}=1.0italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1.0 for the affine shortening stopping time, τ=0.5𝜏0.5\tau=0.5italic_τ = 0.5 for the approximation error threshold, and Imax=3subscript𝐼3I_{\max}=3italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 for the number of iterations. We tested the algorithms on images sampled from the following datasets.

  • •

    SAVOIAS [96]: A dataset of more than 1400 images with sizes ranging from below 200×300×32003003200\times 300\times 3200 × 300 × 3 to above 6000×4000×36000400036000\times 4000\times 36000 × 4000 × 3. Moreover, all images are labeled as seven categories: Scenes, Advertisements, Visualization and infographics, Objects, Interior design, Art, and Suprematism. This dataset was introduced to analyze the visual complexity of images [97].

  • •

    DECOR333https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/olgabelitskaya/traditional-decor-patterns: A collection of 485485485485 color images (150×150×31501503150\times 150\times 3150 × 150 × 3) of traditional decor patterns, which contain rich details and complex shapes.

To reduce noise and artifacts due to JPEG compression, all the input raster images are preprocessed by the FFDNet [109], which is a CNN-based discriminative image denoising technique. This method requires an estimated noise level (0∼255similar-to02550\sim 2550 ∼ 255) which we fix to 10101010 for all clean images. The goal is to alter minimally the shapes present in the images, while removing small noise and JPEG artifacts that should not be kept in any vector representation. A typical way to evaluate the accuracy is to use PSNR which compares pixel values. Since vector graphics are not stored in pixels, it is common to compare vectorization results after converting them back to pixel images via rasterization. Note that rasterization is a non-trivial process, and different implementations can produce images with varying levels of quality. In this paper we consistently use Inkscape444https://inkscape.org for converting vector graphics to raster images in all experiments for the PSNR computation.

6.1 General performances on vectorization

We first illustrate the performances of the proposed vectorization algorithm. We use the Area merging gain (3.9) and test it on images of different styles and sizes. We shall compare different merging criteria in the following subsections.

Figure 8 shows the results. In the first row, we test on a small image of size 150×150150150150\times 150150 × 150. When zoomed with a factor of 3333 and 9999 respectively, the raster image exhibits strong pixelation artifacts, as shown in the left panels. In each right panel, we show the vectorized results containing 88888888 regions in the corresponding scales. Compared to the raster images, the vectorized graphics can be magnified arbitrarily while the quality remains unchanged. In the second row, we show an image with size 500×378500378500\times 378500 × 378 and our vectorized representation contains only N=50𝑁50N=50italic_N = 50 regions. We observe that excessive color variations are present due to antialiasing, especially when the raster image is zoomed by a factor of 9999; our vectorization algorithm effectively removes such undesirable features. We also note that most blue vertical stripes are connected at corners, thus N𝑁Nitalic_N is smaller than the number of stripes. In the third row, the image has size 640×480640480640\times 480640 × 480 and the vectorized result contains N=667𝑁667N=667italic_N = 667 regions. For photographs, the number of regions is usually increased due to complex textures and gradient. In its original scale, we see that the proposed algorithm produces a piecewise constant vector graphic with flexible regions closely approximating the input. The raster image gets blurred when we zoom in, whereas the vector graphic remains clear and the regions’ boundaries identify with objects’ contours and highlight important textures. The Execution Time (ET) for the proposed vectorization is acceptable for practical applications. Using the default number of iterations (Imax=3subscript𝐼3I_{\max}=3italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3), the ET for the small image in the first row is measured at 2.18 seconds; for the image in the second row, it is 3.72 seconds; and for the third row image, it reaches 7.83 seconds. It is observed that the ET increases as the size of the image grows and as it contains more intricate details.

6.2 Region merging criteria and their general behaviors

In this section, we compare the behaviors of the proposed general scheme using different merging gains: MS region merging (3.7), BG region merging (3.6), Scale region merging (3.8), and Area region merging (3.9).

In Figure 9 (a), we show the rasterized La Geisha Kiyoka by Paul Jacoulet (1953) with size 350×450350450350\times 450350 × 450. The regions in the red boxes are zoomed in the column (b), where boundaries show severe pixelation effects. Setting N∗=500superscript𝑁500N^{*}=500italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 500, we show the zoomed vector graphics obtained by Area, BG, Scale, and MS in column (c)-(f), respectively. Observe that both Area and BG preserve more important image features compared to Scale and BG. Strongly influenced by the length minimization, MS tends to overlook shapes with elongated contours, such as the strokes delineating the nose and the flower. Additionally, it does not effectively remove small artifacts along objects’ boundaries due to antialiasing. While Scale successfully eliminates these boundary artifacts, it does not manage to recover intricate details. In contrast, BG retains a greater amount of image detail but struggles to produce clean boundaries. In this example, Area excels at both preserving the image features and removing the blobs along the boundaries, thus yielding the most faithful and efficient representation.

We also test our merging methods on photos. In Figure 10, we focus on comparing different merging methods in three particular regions, and the results are listed in columns (a)-(d) for Area, BG, Scale, and MS. The first region contains smooth transition. Both Scale and MS exhibits strong contouring artifacts; BG shows less severe staircasing; and Area yields the most visually satisfying reconstruction. The second region contains a face, where Area and BG perform similarly while Scale and MS ignore many critical features. The third region contains the shadow of bars with relatively low contrast. Scale and MS fail to keep these recognizable patterns; BG finds it hard to retain all the bars; and Area successfully preserves such details with the highest accuracy.

As explained in Section 5.4, the resulting vector graphics may have fewer than N∗superscript𝑁N^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT regions. In the example shown in Figure 9, there are 444 regions by Area, 415 regions by BG, 356 regions by Scale, and 331 regions by MS, respectively. By plotting the numbers of regions (N𝑁Nitalic_N) corresponding to varying levels of complexity (N∗superscript𝑁N^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) in Figure 11 (a), we see that it is generally the case that MS yields representations with the fewest regions, Scale produces slightly more, whereas both BG and Area render the most regions. However, a smaller N𝑁Nitalic_N does not necessarily correlate with a less accurate representation. Figure 11 (b) shows the relation between N𝑁Nitalic_N and the PSNR of the rasterized vector graphic for different merging methods. For all criteria, increasing N𝑁Nitalic_N generally yields higher PSNR. When N𝑁Nitalic_N is fixed, we observe that Area and BG always achieve higher accuracy than Scale and MS. To reach the highest PSNR value by MS or Scale (N≈350𝑁350N\approx 350italic_N ≈ 350), both Area and BG use only N≈170𝑁170N\approx 170italic_N ≈ 170 regions. The flexibility about the regional contours allows Area and BG quickly adapt to complex shapes in the input image, while the excessive complexity contributes to a minor increment in the PSNR. We investigate the discrepancy of number of regions in Appendix E with more quantitative details.

6.3 Comparison between region merging and color quantization

In this section, we compare the effectiveness of region merging compared with that of color quantization for image vectorization. Figure 12 (a) shows an input raster image for this set of experiments. For vectorization based on color quantization, we test multiple benchmark algorithms including Median Cut (MC) [55], K means++ (Kpp) [13], Incremental Online K-Means (IOKM) [1], Weighted TSE (WTSE) [80], and quantization based on self-organizing Kohonen neural network (NEU) [33]. These algorithms are efficient and commonly integrated into various software. We refer the readers to [21] for a systematic review on related techniques. Using each of these algorithms, we quantize the input with C𝐶Citalic_C colors, where C𝐶Citalic_C varies from 2222 to 16161616. These results respectively induce image partitions, and we color each connected domain with the mean colors of the pixels therein, leading to raster images with no fewer than C𝐶Citalic_C colors. Then we vectorize the resulting color quantized images by applying the same curve smoothing primal step to their discontinuity sets with T∗=1superscript𝑇1T^{*}=1italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1, the default smoothness parameter. The compared region merging methods are MS (3.7), Scale (3.8), and Area (3.9) with their default parameters.

Figure 12 shows the results. We observe that using similar region numbers, the vectorized results based on region merging are more faithful to the original image than those based on quantization techniques. The results in (c)-(f), produced by Area, BG, Scale, and MS region merging respectively, preserve both transitional details in relatively smooth regions such as the sky and the ground, as well as structural details in low-contrast areas such as the woman’s dress in the bottom left and the grass textures on the roof. Noticeably, WTSE in (g) adopts a merging strategy in the color space weighted by the image gradient information. This explains why its result is closer to our proposed scheme. Compared to the other quantization methods, WTSE also shows weaker contouring artifacts. Results in (h)-(k) rely on data clustering techniques applied to color quantization, and they exhibit stronger contouring artifacts in smooth regions. Moreover, they preserve fewer details than the merging methods in (c)-(g).

In Figure 13, we compare the results with more details in the zoom-in regions boxed in (a). In the first group, we notice that the cloud, which is a perceivable feature of the input image, is successfully reconstructed by the proposed scheme using the different region merging criteria. It is merged with the large background region by the other methods. In the second group, most of the quantization-based algorithms fail to recognize the dark blue dress, except for MC. The region-merging method not only identifies the dress, but also distinguishes the grass and mud in the background, which MC mistakenly merges with the shoulder of the woman. In the third group, the contouring artifacts of quantization-based results are accentuated. We find that the region-merging-based approaches and MC are better at recovering fine structure in low-contrast regions. However, MC merges regions with wrong colors, causing low fidelity levels. Among the region merging methods, Area performs the best in terms of detail preservation and smooth region rendering.

Quantitatively, we also compare the different approaches in terms of the PSNR and the complexity of the representation measured by the number of regions in the vector graphics. As shown in Figure 12 (b), all the proposed region-merging-based methods outperform the other color-quantization-based results. More specifically, when represented by roughly the same number of regions, region merging methods yield a closer approximation of the raster input. Note that the regions produced by color quantization are filled with their respective mean colors; thus our comparison reveals the lack of compatibility of the partitions generated by data-clustering in color spaces and the benefit of the proposed region-merging scheme for the task of image vectorization.

6.4 Comparison with state-of-the-art software

In this section, we compare our methods with state-of-the-art software including Adobe Illustrator 2020 (AI)555https://www.adobe.com/products/illustrator.html, Vector Magic (VM)666https://vectormagic.com/, Vectorizer (VZ)777https://www.vectorizer.io/, Vectorizer AI (VAI)888https://vectorizer.ai/, Inkscape (IS)999https://inkscape.org, a network-based vectorization method proposed by Li et al. (DiffVG) [70], and TOP [53] based on color quantization and local boundary surgery. These programs accept raster images of any size and content. In particular, VM allows for low, medium, and high levels of details; VZ allows for min, low, medium, high, very high, maximum, and ultra; for AI, VAI, and IS, the results can be fine-tuned via multiple continuous or discrete parameters. We choose the respective default settings with non-overlapping option in the experiments. For TOP, we apply the Kpp for quantization with 32323232 colors and use the default parameters. For DiffVG, we use the vectorized result from AI as the initialization and run the optimization under the default setting.

Qualitative comparison. We tested the aforementioned methods and our proposed algorithm using different criteria on the image in Figure 9 (a) and show the comparisons in a zoomed-in region in Figure 14. We observe that Area region merging is more natural and faithful than the other results while using small number of regions. Although BG keeps many details, it does not preserve geometric regularity such as the continuity of strokes. Both Scale and MS region merging lead to oversimplification where many elongated strokes are missed. For VM High and Medium, we see that contour strokes are sharp and visually appealing; however, their colors severely deviate from those of the input. We note that VM Medium also wrongly captures the eye as a disk. In VM Low, many details are lost, and some regions are filled with wrong colors, similarly as Scale and MS. The smoothness of AI’s result is close to that of Area, yet many details such as textures of the hair, pupil of the left eye, and the contour line along the cheek are missed. Containing more regions, VAI renders sharper and more faithful line drawings compared to VM; however, the regions with smooth variation are not well represented. The results by VZ with different levels of details are less satisfying. They can create gaps between regions, colors are inaccurate, and fine-scale details are generally not well preserved. The result by DiffVG is visually close to AI, and the result by TOP exhibits false colors due to color quantization. Finally, both IS and VZ max present noticeable gaps among regions, yielding unpleasant results.

To further highlight the strength of our proposed Area region merging method, we compare Area with some representative methods in more details. Figure 15 (a) shows a zoomed-in region of Figure 9 (a), and (b)-(e) show results from Area, AI, VM, and DiffVG. For AI, we applied the automatic simplification, and for VM, we chose the mode High. We have observed that IS and VZ max create undesirable gaps among regions in Figure 14. In (c), we show that such gaps can also appear in AI if simplification or stronger smoothing is employed. In (d), we see that VM renders false geometries and colors which differ from (a). In (e), we see that DiffVG produces transparent and overlapping shapes with irregular contours to minimize overall L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT loss; however, the resulting elements generally do not align with the objects. Area, as shown in (a), avoids the aforementioned defects while successfully removing pixelation effects and faithfully preserving key features of the input image.

Quantitative comparison: similarity and complexity. We quantitatively examine these methods by focusing on the similarity between the rasterized vector graphic and the raster input, and the complexity, i.e., the number of regions (N𝑁Nitalic_N) in the result. Figure 16 collectively shows three sets of comparison where the x𝑥xitalic_x-axis and y𝑦yitalic_y-axis correspond to the number of regions and the PNSR of the output, respectively. For these examples, results from VZ, AI, and VAI are consistently worse compared to the others. In particular, VAI always invokes great numbers of regions, but the results are not faithful to the inputs. For the examples in (a) and (b), Area region merging reaches the highest PSNR with the same number of regions; VM High can achieve similar levels of accuracy, and they are generally higher than Scale region merging and MS region merging. In (c), we show an image where VM consistently yield vector graphics with high qualities which are comparable with Area and BG. We remark that although PSNR is used in this work for evaluating the accuracy, rasterizing vector graphics can underestimate the significance of the Area region merging. For example, removing small regions near boundaries helps to produce visually appealing vector graphics, yet this feature cannot be correctly evaluated after rasterization due to antialiasing.

7 Conclusion

In this work, we explored a generic image vectorization approach combining region merging and curve smoothing. We endowed each image partition with a dual graph linking all pairs of neighboring regions, and a primal graph linking pairs of vertices separated by a single region boundary. Region merging, acting on the dual graph, leverages local color and geometric regularity that are crucial for establishing relations among otherwise unorganized pixel data. Curve smoothing, acting on the primal graph, yields resolution-independent representations for the perceived boundaries. We introduced four merging criteria for the dual step and analyzed the topological consistency issue related to networks of curves evolving under the affine shortening flow. We conducted extensive experiments to validate our models including qualitative and comparison studies. Our results show that the proposed method exhibits interpretable behaviors which can be fine-tuned by user-friendly hyperparameters. Moreover, we concluded from the comparison with color quantization-based approaches that local regularity is critical to the simplicity and visual quality of the vectorized representation. We also illustrated by comparison with state-of-the-art software that the proposed approach is more robust, general, and consistent. Combining the evidence from all experiments, we find that among the four merging schemes, the Area merging method yields the most reliable and faithful results.

Appendix B Proof of Proposition 3.2

where we used Proposition 3.1 for simplifying the numerator of (3.5) and defined ωf2=∑i=1d(sup(fi)−inf(fi))2subscriptsuperscript𝜔2𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑superscriptsupremumsubscript𝑓𝑖infimumsubscript𝑓𝑖2\omega^{2}_{f}=\sum_{i=1}^{d}\left(\sup(f_{i})-\inf(f_{i})\right)^{2}italic_ω start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_sup ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_inf ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the oscillation of f𝑓fitalic_f over ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω, where fi:Ω→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖→Ωℝf_{i}:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : roman_Ω → blackboard_R is the i𝑖iitalic_i-th channel. Appendix E Analysis on the discrepancy of the number of regions

We further investigate the variations in N𝑁Nitalic_N when using different merging methods. In Figure 18 (a), we show how N𝑁Nitalic_N changes after each major step of Algorithm 1 when fixing N∗=100superscript𝑁100N^{*}=100italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 100. The results indicate that the Refine step is primarily responsible for the observed discrepancies in N𝑁Nitalic_N. The Dual step reduces the number of regions by a fixed amount. The Primal step modifies the geometry of partition, which may lead to small regions disappearing, although it does not result in significant changes in N𝑁Nitalic_N overall. In the Refine step, any pairs of adjacent regions with merging costs smaller than λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be merged; here λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the largest cost incurred during the Dual steps. Therefore, the degree of reduction in N𝑁Nitalic_N depends on merging behaviors prior to the Refine step.

To numerically characterize this effect, we define the merging potential at the i𝑖iitalic_i-th merging as follows:

Pi=maxj≤i⁡{Δ⁢Ej}Mi.subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑗𝑖Δsubscript𝐸𝑗subscript𝑀𝑖P_{i}=\frac{\max_{j\leq i}\{\Delta E_{j}\}}{M_{i}}\;.italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ≤ italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_Δ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_ARG start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (E.1)

Here Δ⁢EjΔsubscript𝐸𝑗\Delta E_{j}roman_Δ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the merging cost for the j𝑗jitalic_j-th merging, and Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the average of the merging costs of all pairs of adjacent regions right after the i𝑖iitalic_i-th merging occurs. Particularly, suppose i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the number of merging right before the Refine step, then maxj≤i∗⁡{Δ⁢Ej}=λ∗subscript𝑗superscript𝑖Δsubscript𝐸𝑗superscript𝜆\max_{j\leq i^{*}}\{\Delta E_{j}\}=\lambda^{*}roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ≤ italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_Δ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is large, either the average merging cost becomes low or the maximal merging cost grows higher, and both scenarios lead to potentially more regions to be merged during the Refine step. In Figure 18 (b), we see that the merging potentials for all methods generally grow as the merging proceeds. After around 1.40×1051.40superscript1051.40\times 10^{5}1.40 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT merging, we find in (c) that the merging potential for Area and BG grows slowly, that for Scale grows faster, and that for MS grows exponentially fast. Around the 1.53×1051.53superscript1051.53\times 10^{5}1.53 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-th merging, the merging potential for Scale reaches a peak; around the 1.54×1051.54superscript1051.54\times 10^{5}1.54 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-th merging, the potentials for BG and Area reach their respective peaks; and around the 1.55×1051.55superscript1051.55\times 10^{5}1.55 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-th merging, MS attains its highest peak. The potential drops following these peaks indicate that the average merging costs increase significantly. They correspond to phases when groups of regions with similar merging costs are being merged. Associated with different choices of gains, these merged regions have different geometric features compared to those merged before the peaks. Notice that the merging potentials slightly increase after the drops, indicating another phase of merging. In (d), we focus on the last hundreds of merging, and the dashed lines indicate when the Refine steps start. In particular, we see that the merging potential of Scale is the highest, MS is the second, BG is the third, and Area is the lowest. Except for BG, this aligns well with the rank of the numbers of regions reduced after refining. See Figure 18 (d). the dashed lines indicate that MS reaches N=100𝑁100N=100italic_N = 100 first, followed by Scale in second place, BG in third, and Area last. Given that the number of reduced regions from the Dual steps are fixed, these variances arise from the Primal steps where regions disappear due to the affine shortening flow. This is consistent with the fact that MS favors regions with shorter perimeters, which are more likely to vanish during the Primal steps.

In Figure 18 (d), we report N𝑁Nitalic_N and PSNR of the results before and after the Refine step for different merging criteria. We see that before refining, all methods yield the identical number of regions specified by N∗superscript𝑁N^{*}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; and Area achieves the highest PSNR. After refining, both Scale and MS removes over 10101010 regions resulting more reduction in the approximation accuracy. In contrast, both Area and BG retain better quality while eliminating fewer regions. To quantify the impact of the Refine step on the representation quality, we define the region importance as

S=Reduction in PSNR after RefineReduction in ⁢N⁢ after Refine.𝑆Reduction in PSNR after RefineReduction in 𝑁 after RefineS=\frac{\text{Reduction in PSNR after Refine}}{\text{Reduction in }N\text{ % after Refine}}\;.italic_S = divide start_ARG Reduction in PSNR after Refine end_ARG start_ARG Reduction in italic_N after Refine end_ARG . (E.2)

It can be interpreted as the reduced PSNR per removed region. We see that MS has the highest region importance among these criteria. It implies that each region produced by MS carries much information, thus removing any of them leads to significant quality degradation. With less restrictions on the shapes of contours, both BG and Area have higher tolerance on the region reduction.
